Chapter 5

Ok now chapter 5. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Opening Night Halloween week at Frightmare Manor is usually my favorite time of year. Tonight, watching fake zombies stumble past fake vampires while fake blood drips aesthetically down fake walls, all I could think about was how many places someone could hide a real body. "Stop catastrophizing," Mira whispered through my headset. She'd convinced Marcus she was my new effects assistant. "Jamie's fine. He's probably just being a dramatic teenager." "He's not answering his phone." "Because he's at football practice. I checked his schedule." "How do you have his schedule?" "I have everyone's schedule. For investigative purposes." I should probably be worried about that, but right now I was more worried about the crowd forming outside the effects room. Halloween week means endless complaints about makeup and prosthetics. "The blood keeps dripping in my eyes," zombie number three was saying. "That's because you keep touching it," I replied automatically, while scanning the queue for Jamie. He had to be here somewhere. "Just leave it alone and-" My phone buzzed. SUCH A GOOD SISTER ALWAYS HELPING OTHERS SHAME YOU COULDN'T HELP ELLIE OR JAMIE "Ignore it," Mira said in my ear. "They're just trying to get to you." Another buzz. WANT TO KNOW WHAT YOUR BROTHER SAW? MEET ME IN THE BASEMENT ALONE "Don't even think about it," Mira warned. "I wasn't." "You were. I can hear you thinking about it." She was right. But before I could reply, I spotted something in the zombie queue. A familiar hoodie. Jamie's hoodie. But not Jamie wearing it. I pushed through the zombies, ignoring their complaints about smudged makeup. The person in Jamie's hoodie disappeared around a corner. "What are you doing?" Mira asked. "Following a lead." "What lead?" "Jamie's hoodie." "On who?" "Don't know yet." The figure was always just ahead, just around the next corner, just out of reach. Leading me deeper into the manor, past the public areas, towards the old basement stairs. My phone buzzed again. GETTING WARMER "Penny, wait," Mira said. "This is literally how every horror movie starts." "Got a better idea?" "Several. All involving not following mysterious figures into basements." But I was already heading down the stairs. The figure had disappeared, but Jamie's hoodie was draped over the basement door handle. My phone lit up. GETTING VERY WARM "Mira?" "Still here. Still thinking this is a terrible idea." "If I'm not back in five minutes..." "Already called backup." "What backup?" "Don't ask questions you don't want answered." The basement door creaked open. Because of course it did. Everything about this was becoming horrifically cliché. My torch beam caught something red on the floor. A trail of drops leading deeper into the basement. Real blood this time. I was sure of it. The consistency was wrong for my recipe. Too thin. Too metallic. My phone buzzed one last time. BOILING HOT "Penny?" Mira's voice was breaking up. "Signal's... losing you..." The headset crackled and went dead. Of course it did. The blood trail led to the old props storage room. The door was slightly open. A light was on inside. I should wait for Mira's mysterious backup. I should call the police. I should do anything except what I was about to do. I pushed the door open. The room was full of old set pieces and broken props. And there, in the center, was Jamie's phone. Playing a video. Of Jamie. In the effects room. Last Tuesday. He was hiding behind a shelf, filming something. The camera shook as he whispered, "I knew it. I knew something weird was happening. Look at-" The video cut off. My phone buzzed. WANT TO SEE HOW IT ENDS? Another buzz. CHECK THE SUPPLY CUPBOARD The supply cupboard door was closed. A red handprint marked the handle. I reached for it. Stopped. Looked closer at the handprint. Something wasn't right. The consistency was... "Oh," I said out loud. "Oh, you absolute-" I touched the handprint. Still wet. But not blood. My recipe. My exact recipe. Down to the coffee undertones and chocolate powder base. Which meant... "Looking for this?" I turned. And there was Jamie, very much alive, holding an empty bottle of my fake blood. And grinning. "Got you," he said. Then the lights went out. And my phone buzzed one final time. FOUND YOU But not from the unknown number this time. From Jamie's phone. The one that was supposedly on the floor in front of me. The one that was now lighting up someone else's face in the darkness. Someone holding something that looked a lot like my special effects knife. Except the blade was real. And so was the blood on it.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 5)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively captures the intended darkly comic British YA tone, blending genuine suspense with character-driven humor. The narrative follows Penny during the opening night of Halloween week at Frightmare Manor, advancing both the mysterious blood emoji plot and character relationships. The chapter demonstrates strengths in its consistent first-person voice and authentic teen dynamics. Penny's internal thoughts match her established character profile as someone detail-oriented about effects work but anxious about personal matters. The dialogue between Penny and Mira feels natural and reflects their established rapport, with Mira's protective "I have everyone's schedule. For investigative purposes" capturing her characterization well. However, the chapter deviates somewhat from the original plan. While it does include Penny juggling investigation and work, there's no mention of parents fighting about drama school or any connection to drama school rejection letters. The chapter instead focuses entirely on the mystery elements, potentially at the expense of the deeper character development outlined in the plan. The pacing is effective, building tension gradually while maintaining the darkly comic tone. Lines like "Everything about this was becoming horrifically cliché" show self-awareness that prevents the story from becoming too serious or formulaic. The chapter skillfully balances teen dialogue with genuine suspense. The plot twist with Jamie appearing alive works well, but the final revelation of another person with a real knife feels somewhat rushed. The chapter could have benefited from more subtle foreshadowing of this double twist rather than relying primarily on the classic horror trope of basement exploration. The mystery elements sometimes overshadow character development, which may make the stakes feel lower than they could be if we had seen more of Penny's relationship with Jamie earlier in the chapter. While the prose avoids being purple, it occasionally slips into telling rather than showing, particularly in the quick explanations of emotional states rather than demonstrating them through action. The dialogue generally avoids this problem, with exchanges that efficiently reveal character while advancing the plot. The chapter succeeds in maintaining the British YA tone established in the writing prompt, with appropriate teen voice and enough suspense to create genuine stakes. The three blood emoji mystery is central to the plot, though the connection to the broader narrative goals (like Penny's drama school aspirations) isn't clearly established in this chapter alone. Chapter 6

Ok now chapter 6. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Stage Fright "Run," Jamie whispered. I grabbed his arm and pulled him behind a stack of old set pieces as the knife-wielding figure stepped into the room. In the dim light from their phone screen, I could see they were wearing one of our zombie masks. One of my zombie masks. The good ones, with the detailed decomposition around the jaw. Professionally insulting, really. Jamie was trembling. I squeezed his arm, hoping it felt reassuring rather than terrified. "When I said I needed to show you something," he whispered, "this wasn't it." "What was it?" "Last week I saw someone stealing your recipe book. I tried to film them but-" A prop crashed nearby. We both jumped. "Come out, come out," sang a voice. Familiar, but distorted by the mask. "Don't you want to know what happened to Ellie?" Jamie's hand tightened on my arm. "Penny, I think they-" "Shh." More props falling. Closer now. My phone buzzed. I silenced it without looking, but not before the light gave away our position. "There you are!" We ran. Through the basement, up the stairs, past surprised zombies and vampires who probably thought this was part of the show. My headset was still dead. No way to call for help. "The effects room," Jamie panted. "We can lock ourselves in." "They'll have the key." "But all your weapons are fake." "They don't know that." We sprinted down the corridor, dodging confused customers. Behind us, the masked figure walked calmly, unhurried. Like they knew something we didn't. The effects room door was open. It shouldn't have been open. "Wait-" I started, but Jamie was already running in. The door slammed behind him. Leaving me in the corridor. With the masked figure at one end. And another figure, wearing my spare zombie mask, at the other. My phone buzzed. SURPRISE "Penny!" Jamie's voice from inside the effects room. "They've blocked the door!" I looked between the two masked figures. Both holding real knives. Both moving closer. Think, think, think. What would a horror movie character do? Die, probably. What would a special effects expert do? I reached into my pocket and pulled out my emergency fake blood capsules. The ones that burst on impact. And threw them at the nearest light fixture. Red liquid exploded across the bulb. The corridor went dark. Someone swore. I dropped to the ground as the figures crashed into each other in the darkness. Crawled to the effects room door. "Jamie! The window!" "It's stuck!" "Use the fake arm!" "What?" "The prosthetic arm! In the box by the desk! Use it to break the window!" A crash from inside. Then another crash behind me as one of the masked figures found the light switch. The corridor blazed back into view. Both figures were still standing. Both still armed. Both looking at me. My phone buzzed one last time. GAME OVER But they'd forgotten something. This was Halloween week. Which meant... "NOW!" I screamed. Right on cue, the manor's automated scream track started playing at full volume. The figures flinched. Just for a second. But long enough for Jamie to reach through the broken window and unlock the effects room door from the outside. Long enough for me to dive through. Long enough to slam it shut behind me and turn the lock. "What now?" Jamie asked, bleeding slightly from where he'd broken the window. I looked around my effects room. At all my carefully organized supplies. My perfectly crafted fake weapons. And smiled. "Now," I said, "we show them what practical effects can really do." I grabbed my recipe book and turned to the section marked 'Emergency Contingencies.' "Jamie, how do you feel about being a stunt double?" He grinned. "Will it involve explosions?" "If we do it right." Behind us, someone started banging on the door. "They'll break through eventually," Jamie said. "Good." "Good?" I pulled out my special effects kit. The industrial one. The one with the theatrical smoke capsules and quick-change prosthetics. "Let them come," I said. "This is my stage." My phone buzzed one last time. FINAL ACT BEGINNING BREAK A LEG LITERALLY "Ready?" I asked Jamie. He picked up a bottle of fake blood. "Ready." The door began to splinter. Time for the performance of my life. Literally.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 6)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter attempts to deliver a suspenseful, high-stakes sequence in a darkly comic British YA story, but falls short in several areas despite some promising elements. The pacing is the chapter's strongest feature. The action moves quickly with short, punchy paragraphs that create genuine tension. The author effectively builds suspense with interrupted dialogue, abrupt revelations, and escalating danger. This technique works well for the genre and target audience. However, the characters lack depth in this chapter. While Penny shows some of her special effects expertise, her voice isn't particularly distinctive or authentically British teen-like. The dialogue between Penny and Jamie is functional but generic - there's little that makes it specifically sound like these characters as described in their profiles. Jamie's characterization is especially thin; beyond mentioning he's trembling, we get little insight into his personality or the sibling dynamic. The setting feels underdeveloped. "Frightmare Manor" should be atmospheric and distinct, but we get minimal description of the space, making it difficult to visualize the chase sequence. The "effects room" and other locations are mentioned without bringing them to life through sensory details. The chapter relies heavily on telling rather than showing. Lines like "We both jumped" and "More props falling" tell us what's happening without creating vivid imagery. The emotional states are often directly stated rather than conveyed through specific physical reactions or thought processes. Plot-wise, the chapter sticks to the basic structure from the plan but rushes through important elements. The revelation about Ellie is thrown in without context, and the masked figures' motivations remain completely opaque. The text messages feel like plot devices rather than organic communications. The ending attempts to create a cliffhanger and showcase Penny's expertise, but it feels contrived. The convenient timing of the automated scream track and Penny's sudden confidence shift strain credibility. The "this is my stage" line and final text message are tonally inconsistent with the genuine peril established earlier. Regarding British authenticity, there's nothing specifically British about the language or cultural references. Terms like "effects room" and "zombies" are generic, and we get no sense of British teenage speech patterns or slang. The dark comedy element is almost entirely absent. Despite the chapter plan promising a balance of "genuine creepiness and humor," the chapter offers suspense without the darkly comic tone promised in the prompt. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 7 Emotionally Engaging: 9 Compelling Plot: 10 Coherent: 12 Weak Dialogue: 13 Tell-Don't-Show: 14 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 12 Amateurish: 10 Purple Prose: 5 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 6 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 8 Characters Consistent with Profile: 9 Followed Chapter Plan: 11 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 10

Chapter 7

Ok now chapter 7. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Technical Difficulties The thing about practical effects is that they only have to work once. And they have to work perfectly. No second takes in live performance. As the door splintered, I ran through the plan one last time. "Smoke capsules?" I whispered. Jamie held them up. "Check." "Quick-change prosthetics?" "Check." "Emergency blood packs?" "Triple check." "Mira's backup?" "What backup?" The door crashed open. Showtime. The first masked figure stepped through the smoke capsules we'd thrown, knife raised. The second followed, moving more cautiously. "That's a terrible mask," I said to the first one. "The latex work is sloppy." They lunged. I ducked. Jamie triggered the blood pack. Red sprayed across the room, catching both figures by surprise. While they were distracted, I grabbed my emergency kit and ran for the supply closet. "After her!" one of them shouted. Still familiar. Still distorted. I slammed the closet door and started the quick-change. The fastest costume switch I'd ever attempted, and this time it actually mattered. Outside, I heard Jamie yell, then a crash. Faster, faster. More crashes. Almost done. "Found you," said a voice right outside the closet. The door flew open. But I wasn't there. Instead, they found themselves face to face with... themselves. I'd copied their mask exactly. Down to the badly done latex work. In the confusion, I slipped past them into the effects room. Where I found Jamie wrestling with the second figure, who was trying to reach something on the high shelf. My recipe book. "It was never about Ellie, was it?" I said. "This was about my recipes." The first figure laughed behind their mask. "Finally figured it out?" "The blood drops were a bit obvious. Real blood doesn't dry like that." "Noticed that, did you?" "I noticed you used my recipe. Badly." That got them. They stepped forward, knife raised. "Badly?" "Amateur work. Too much corn syrup." "You think you're so clever." "Clever enough to know who you are." They stopped. "Really?" "The drama teacher wouldn't get the recipe wrong." Behind them, Jamie's eyes widened. He got it. "Security wouldn't care about consistency." The figure took another step. "But someone who lost the lead makeup artist job to a teenager?" They lunged. I threw my last smoke capsule. The room filled with theatrical fog. Someone screamed. Something crashed. A knife clattered to the floor. The smoke began to clear. And there was Sophie Miller, her zombie mask fallen off, being held down by... Mira? "Took you long enough," I said. "Dramatic timing," Mira replied, sitting on Sophie while texting someone. "Also, traffic." The second figure tried to run. Right into Leo from tech crew, holding what looked like a real cricket bat. "That's not a prop," he said helpfully. Sophie was crying now. "It's not fair! I trained for years and they gave the job to you!" "So you decided to steal my recipes?" "And frame you for Ellie's disappearance," Mira added. "Speaking of which..." The police burst in. Actually burst in, like in a movie. "Perfect timing," Mira said. "I told you when to arrive for maximum dramatic effect." Sophie was still talking. "It was supposed to be simple. Steal the recipes, scare you into quitting, make it look like you were involved with Ellie..." "Where is Ellie?" one of the police officers asked. Sophie laughed. "At her aunt's in Bristol. I just paid her to turn off her phone for a few days. Made the blood texts more convincing." "The blood texts were a bit much," I said. "Had to make it dramatic. You always said theatre needs drama." "Speaking of drama," Jamie cut in, "can someone explain why Leo and Mira were ready with a cricket bat?" "I called them," he said. "After I saw Sophie stealing your recipes. But then she caught me filming..." "So you decided to play along?" "Wanted to catch her properly. With evidence." "And you didn't tell me because..." "You're a terrible actor." "I am not!" "Remember the year three nativity?" "I was a convincing sheep!" "You were not." Sophie started laughing hysterically as the police led her away. "You're all insane. This whole place is insane." "Says the person who sent blood emoji texts," Mira muttered. My phone buzzed one last time. NICE PERFORMANCE SHAME ABOUT THE ENDING BUT THERE'S ALWAYS THE SEQUEL "That's not Sophie's phone," Jamie said. We all looked at each other. Then at the second mask on the floor. The one Leo hadn't caught. The one that was missing. Along with my recipe book. "Oh," I said. "Oh no," said Mira. My phone buzzed again. INTERMISSION OVER ACT TWO BEGINNING BREAK A LEG FOR REAL THIS TIME
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 7)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter represents the climactic confrontation of the story, where Penny and Jamie face off against the mysterious figures behind the blood emoji texts. The writing successfully maintains the darkly comic tone requested in the prompt, balancing genuine tension with humorous elements like Penny critiquing her attacker's mask work. The chapter demonstrates strengths in its pacing and plot twists. The revelation of Sophie Miller as one antagonist works effectively, with her motivation (professional jealousy over losing the makeup artist job to Penny) providing a plausible explanation for the events. The final twist—that there's still another conspirator at large—creates a compelling cliffhanger that subverts expectations just when readers might think the mystery is solved. Character-wise, Penny's expertise in special effects is well-utilized in the confrontation, showing how her passion becomes practical in a crisis. This is consistent with her character profile. Jamie's supportive role also aligns with his profile as someone who secretly appreciates Penny's talents while maintaining their sibling rivalry. The unexpected appearances of Mira and Leo demonstrate the ensemble nature of the story effectively. However, the chapter has some weaknesses. The action sequences occasionally lack clarity—it's sometimes difficult to visualize exactly what's happening during the confrontation. Some dialogue feels slightly forced or expository, particularly when Sophie explains her plan. The chapter also relies heavily on coincidental timing (Mira and Leo arriving at the perfect moment), which stretches credibility. The writing follows the chapter plan well, incorporating the Halloween show chaos, the culprit reveal, Penny's effects knowledge saving the day, and ending with unresolved elements. However, the connection to the drama school rejection letters mentioned in the plan isn't clearly developed in this chapter. While the chapter effectively uses Penny's special effects knowledge as both plot device and character development, some of the technical details feel underdeveloped. The "quick-change" and prosthetics could be described more vividly to really showcase Penny's expertise. Overall, this is a solid chapter that delivers on the premise of darkly comic British YA fiction while maintaining narrative momentum and character consistency. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 14 Emotionally Engaging: 13 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 16 Weak Dialogue: 7 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 7 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Characters Consistent with Profile: 17 Followed Chapter Plan: 15 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 16

Chapter 8

Ok now finish the story with chapter 8. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Notes from the Director The thing about being a special effects artist is that you learn to appreciate good theatre. And whoever took my recipe book? That was good theatre. Two weeks after the Sophie incident, things had mostly returned to normal. Ellie was back from Bristol, extremely apologetic about the whole thing. The police had closed the case. Even my parents had calmed down about finding out I'd been secretly applying to drama schools. "It shows initiative," Dad had said, surprisingly. "Very entrepreneurial." "The special effects industry is actually quite profitable," Mum added, less surprisingly. Jamie was unofficially my assistant now, which mostly meant he stole less of my supplies. Mira had taken down her evidence wall, though I caught her adding new string sometimes when she thought I wasn't looking. Everything was fine. Except. "The consistency is wrong," I said, examining the latest blood splatter at Frightmare. "Too thick." "Maybe they're still learning," Mira suggested. "They have my recipe book." "Maybe they're improving it." "Nobody improves my recipes." My phone buzzed. EVERYONE'S A CRITIC I didn't jump anymore when these came through. They'd become almost routine. Every few days, a new message. Always about blood. Always about theatre. Never threatening anymore. More like... notes from a director. GOOD SCENE TODAY LIGHTING NEEDS WORK BLOOD SPLATTER TOO OBVIOUS "You know who it is, don't you?" Jamie asked one night, while we were cleaning prosthetics. "I have theories." "Going to share them?" "Not yet." "Why not?" Because sometimes good theatre needs mystery. Because sometimes the not knowing is better than the knowing. Because sometimes... My phone buzzed. READY FOR YOUR NEXT PERFORMANCE? I smiled. "Because they're not done teaching." Jamie rolled his eyes. "You're both weird, you know that?" "Both?" "You and whoever's sending these. Proper theatre people." "There's nothing proper about us." "That's what I mean." My phone buzzed again. DRAMA SCHOOL AUDITION TOMORROW BREAK A LEG NO BLOOD REQUIRED THIS TIME I looked at my perfectly organized effects room. At my carefully labeled bottles of fake blood. At the empty space where my recipe book used to be. And realized something. I didn't need it anymore. I'd memorized those recipes years ago. The book was just for show. Just theatre. Like the blood emoji texts had been theatre. Like Sophie's mask had been theatre. Like everything in this haunted house was theatre. My phone buzzed one last time. GOOD LUCK YOU'LL NAIL IT YOU ALWAYS DO - THE DIRECTOR "Are you ever going to tell me who it is?" Jamie asked. "Would it make a better story if I did?" He thought about it. "Probably not." "Then no." I picked up a bottle of my latest recipe. The consistency was perfect. Better than the old one. Because whoever took my book was right - there's always room for improvement. Even in fake blood. Even in theatre. Even in life. My phone buzzed again. But this time it was Mira: Found new evidence!!!! Come quick!!! I looked at Jamie. He grinned. "Ready for the sequel?" he asked. "Always." Because that's the other thing about theatre. The show must go on. Even if it's just three blood drops at midnight. Even if it's just texts from an unknown number. Even if it's just fake blood and real mystery and the space between performance and reality. The curtain never really falls. It just waits for the next act to begin. My phone buzzed one final time. 🩸🩸🩸 I smiled. Showtime.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 8)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This final chapter offers a somewhat satisfying, if slightly too tidy, resolution to the blood emoji mystery. The author attempts to balance closure with lingering mystery, but leans too heavily on vague, self-satisfied teasing rather than substantive intrigue. The writing shows an understanding of YA voice, with Penny's internal narrative capturing the self-assured teenage perspective. However, this voice occasionally slips into an affected, almost pretentious tone that undermines authenticity, particularly in lines like "The curtain never really falls. It just waits for the next act to begin." Such moments feel less like genuine teen thought and more like an adult writer straining for profundity. Character consistency is mostly maintained. Penny's perfectionism about special effects and her complicated relationship with Jamie come through clearly. The interactions between siblings feel natural, especially Jamie's eye-rolling and Penny's protective expertise. The parents' acceptance of her drama school ambitions aligns with the "entrepreneurial" mindset established in their profiles. The plot resolution, however, feels underdeveloped. The text implies that someone stole Penny's recipe book and is now sending her cryptic "director's notes," but deliberately withholds concrete answers. While mystery can be effective, this approach reads less like artistic ambiguity and more like the author avoiding the challenge of crafting a satisfying explanation. The vague "Sophie incident" and "Ellie... back from Bristol" references assume reader knowledge without providing enough context for this standalone chapter assessment. The chapter suffers from excessive telling over showing, particularly regarding the emotional impact of events. Lines like "Everything was fine. Except." rely on artificial dramatic formatting rather than earned tension. The dialogue tends toward exposition ("You know who it is, don't you?") or thematic announcement rather than natural conversation. In terms of creativity, the chapter shows potential in its theatrical metaphors and the transformation of threatening messages into "notes from a director," but doesn't fully develop these ideas beyond surface cleverness. The repetitive structure of short, one-sentence paragraphs creates a stylized effect that sometimes works but often feels mechanical. Overall, this chapter demonstrates competent YA writing with a grasp of teen dynamics, but is weakened by an over-reliance on portentous statements, deliberately withheld information, and a resolution that prioritizes thematic neat-tying over narrative satisfaction. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 13 Emotionally Engaging: 11 Compelling Plot: 10 Coherent: 14 Weak Dialogue: 12 Tell-Don't Show: 13 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 10 Amateurish: 8 Purple Prose: 9 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 11 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 12 Characters Consistent with Profile: 15 Followed Chapter Plan: 16 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 15

Final Piece Evaluation

Judge Response (First Entry):
[Analysis] This darkly comic British YA story successfully delivers a blend of horror-comedy with a distinctive voice that feels authentically teenage. The narrative follows Penny, a special effects makeup artist at Frightmare Manor, who receives mysterious blood emoji texts that coincide with a classmate's disappearance. The protagonist's characterization is the strongest element. Penny's passion for practical effects and her conflict between pursuing drama school versus her parents' expectations of a "sensible career" creates a believable teenage character. Her technical knowledge of fake blood recipes provides both character depth and an interesting plot device. Her relationship with her brother Jamie and friend Mira feels authentic, with dialogue that captures sibling dynamics and teenage friendship. The pacing is generally effective, building tension with the mysterious texts and Ellie's disappearance, though it occasionally relies too heavily on phone notifications to move the plot forward. The resolution feels somewhat rushed and anticlimactic, with Sophie's capture and explanation happening too quickly and neatly. The world-building creates a convincing setting of a British haunted house attraction and sixth form life. Details about special effects work add authenticity, though the school environment sometimes feels thinly sketched. Dialogue is one of the story's strengths, particularly between Penny and Mira, capturing teenage speech patterns without becoming caricatured. The "proper proper creepy" line and their discussions about true crime podcasts feel genuinely adolescent. The story does occasionally tell rather than show, particularly when explaining character motivations or backstory. There are moments where emotional states are directly stated rather than demonstrated through action or dialogue. While the premise of mysterious blood emoji texts is creative, the revelation that it was about stealing makeup recipes feels underwhelming after the buildup. The secondary mystery with "The Director" remains deliberately unresolved, which works well for the tone but may frustrate readers seeking complete closure. The writing avoids purple prose and forced metaphors, maintaining an appropriately light touch for YA fiction. The technical descriptions of fake blood have just enough detail to be interesting without becoming excessive. Overall, this is a competent YA mystery with a distinctive protagonist and setting. Its strengths lie in voice, dialogue, and the unusual backdrop of special effects makeup, while its weaknesses include some plot convenience and an occasionally rushed pace. [Scores] Believable Character Actions: 16 Nuanced Characters: 15 Pacing: 14 World Building: 15 Compelling Plot: 13 Emotionally Engaging: 14 Coherent: 16 Weak Dialogue: 5 Tell-Don't-Show: 8 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 6 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Unearned Transformations: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18
Avg Final Item Score: 74.9/100
+ Space Western — Cargo Unknown (Chapter Avg: 74.6 | Final: 72.8)
Initial Writing Prompt:
Space Western Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: Captain, something's... moving in that crate we picked up.
+ Planning Phase (5 Steps)
Space Western Write a short story over several chapters to this prompt: Captain, something&#x27;s... moving in that crate we picked up. -- Your task is to create a writing plan for this prompt. The scope will be a short story, written over {n_chapters} chapters. Each chapter will be approximately 1000 words so plan accordingly for this scope. Your plan should be comprehensive and in this format: # Brainstorming <Brainstorm ideas for characters, plot, tone, story beats, pacing over the {n_chapters} chapters. The purpose of brainstorming is to cast a wide net of ideas, not to settle on any specific direction. Think about various ways you could take the prompt.> # Reflection <Reflect out loud on what works and doesn't work in these ideas. The purpose of this reflection is to narrow in on what you think will work best to make a piece that is a. compelling, and b. fits the prompt requirements. You are not making any decisons just yet, just reflecting.>
Model Output:
# Brainstorming Characters: - Gruff but principled cargo ship captain - Young, tech-savvy engineer - Mysterious corporate agent/client - Veteran security officer - Ship's doctor with questionable past - The "something" in the crate - alien? Experiment? Illegal tech? Setting Elements: - Small independent cargo vessel - Remote space routes between frontier colonies - Dusty spaceports with Western vibes - Corporate outposts - Asteroid mining settlements Potential Plot Directions: 1. Bio-weapon escape scenario: Creature breaks loose, crew must contain 2. Moral dilemma: Living cargo that needs help vs contract obligations 3. Corporate conspiracy: Crate contents tied to larger plot 4. Horror survival: Unknown entity picks off crew one by one 5. Rescue mission: Something/someone in crate needs saving 6. Heist gone wrong: Crew discovers they're unwitting accomplices Tone Options: - Suspenseful horror - Action-adventure - Character-driven drama - Mystery/thriller - Dark comedy Story Beat Ideas: - Discovery of movement in crate - Initial investigation - First contact/conflict - Crew division over what to do - Revelation of true nature - Chase/containment sequence - Moral choice point - Resolution/aftermath # Reflection The bio-weapon/creature escape feels somewhat overdone, though it could work if given a fresh angle. The moral dilemma direction seems more interesting and allows for deeper character development. The Western elements need to be more than just aesthetic - they should inform the story's themes about frontier justice and individual moral codes versus authority. A pure horror approach might be too limiting - better to blend suspense with character drama and moral complexity. The "something in the crate" should drive character decisions rather than just be a threat. The corporate conspiracy angle could work well as a backdrop but shouldn't overshadow the immediate drama of the crew's situation. The most compelling elements seem to be: - Focus on captain's moral choices - Crew dynamics under pressure - Balance of immediate danger with larger implications - Western themes of frontier justice and individual conscience - Mystery that reveals itself gradually rather than all at once The story might work best as a character-driven suspense piece that uses the "something in the crate" as a catalyst for exploring deeper themes about responsibility and moral choices in lawless space. Would need to ensure the pacing maintains tension while allowing for character development across 8 chapters.
Great now let's continue with planning the short story. Output in this format: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention This will be a character-driven suspense story that blends Space Western elements with moral complexity. The story will follow a principled but struggling cargo ship captain who discovers something alive in a supposedly routine cargo shipment. Key intentions: - Focus on moral choices rather than action sequences - Use Western tropes purposefully (frontier justice, individual vs authority) - Maintain mystery about crate contents until mid-story reveal - Explore crew dynamics under pressure - Keep the scope contained (mostly on ship, small cast) - Write in limited third person from captain's perspective - Balance tension with character moments - Avoid typical monster/alien tropes - Emphasize the "frontier space" setting through details and atmosphere The "something in the crate" will be revealed to be genetically engineered children being transported as corporate property, forcing the captain to choose between contract law and moral duty. # Chapter Planning Chapter 1: "The Cargo" - Introduce Captain Sarah Chen and her small crew - Establish their struggling cargo business - Show pickup of mysterious crate from corporate facility - End with discovery of movement in crate Chapter 2: "First Watch" - Initial investigation attempts - Growing tension between crew members - Corporate agent contacts ship about "routine check" - Strange sounds/activity escalate Chapter 3: "Breaking Point" - Security officer advocates breaking open crate - Engineer discovers troubling life sign readings - Captain's first moral challenge regarding contract - End with decision to open crate Chapter 4: "The Truth" - Discovery of engineered children - Immediate crew reactions/conflict - Corporate agent demands status update - Captain must make initial choice about reporting Chapter 5: "Pursuit" - Corporate ships appear on radar - Crew splits on what to do - Chase through asteroid field - Haven colony contact made Chapter 6: "Safe Harbor" - Arrival at independent colony - Meeting with colony leadership - Corporate threats escalate - Crew must choose sides Chapter 7: "Stand" - Corporate forces arrive - Captain faces final moral choice - Crew unites for plan - Colony supports resistance Chapter 8: "New Horizon" - Resolution of immediate conflict - Decisions about children's fate - Consequences for crew - Open ending suggesting new purpose for captain/crew Each chapter will maintain focus on Captain Chen's perspective while exploring crew dynamics and moral choices. The Western elements will be especially prominent in the haven colony chapters.
With a view to making the writing more human, discuss how a human might approach this particular piece (given the original prompt). Discuss telltale LLM approaches to writing (generally) and ways they might not serve this particular piece. For example, common LLM failings are to write safely, or to always wrap things up with a bow, or trying to write impressively at the expense of readability. Then do a deep dive on the intention & plan, critiquing ways it might be falling into typical LLM tropes & pitfalls. Brainstorm ideas to make it more human. Be comprehensive. We aren't doing any rewriting of the plan yet, just critique & brainstorming.
Model Output:
# LLM Writing Tendencies vs Human Approach Common LLM Pitfalls: - Over-explanation and excessive exposition - "Perfect" character arcs that feel manufactured - Predictable moral lessons - Risk-averse plotting - Tidy resolutions - Character emotions described rather than shown - Dialogue that serves plot rather than feeling natural - Tendency to make everything significant/meaningful - Overuse of established tropes without subversion How a Human Might Approach This: - Start with the visceral ("something moving in a crate" is inherently unsettling) - Let uncertainty and messiness drive the story - Allow for genuine surprise in the writing process - Include seemingly pointless details that add texture - Write from gut feelings rather than plot requirements - Allow characters to be inconsistent/irrational - Include humor in unexpected places - Leave some threads deliberately unresolved # Critical Analysis of Current Plan Problems in Current Approach: 1. The moral dilemma feels too clean - Corporate bad guys vs good captain is oversimplified - The "engineered children" reveal is almost too perfect a moral test 2. Structure is too neat - Each chapter fulfills its expected role - Progression feels mechanical rather than organic - Too much happens exactly when it should 3. Characters seem designed to serve plot - Crew members represent positions rather than people - Conflicts feel engineered for drama - Missing the mundane interactions that make characters real 4. Western elements feel superficial - Currently more aesthetic than thematic - Missing the grit and moral ambiguity of actual Westerns # Ideas for Humanizing 1. Messier Motivations: - Maybe the captain initially wants to ignore the movement - Corporate agent could be sympathetic but bound by system - Crew members might have competing personal stakes - Haven colony could have ulterior motives 2. Unexpected Elements: - Ship has persistent mechanical problems - Crew deals with mundane issues alongside crisis - Personal relationships complicate decisions - Some comic relief in tense moments 3. Deeper Western Integration: - Frontier justice isn't always moral justice - Explore gray areas of law vs conscience - Include actual danger/lawlessness of space - Show cost of "doing right" in wrong system 4. Character Complexity: - Give characters odd quirks unrelated to plot - Show private moments that reveal personality - Include backstory that doesn't "pay off" - Allow for irrational decisions 5. Structural Looseness: - Let some chapters end unceremoniously - Include "dead time" that builds atmosphere - Allow for digressions that don't advance plot - Leave some mysteries unexplained 6. Tonal Variation: - Mix humor with tension - Include quiet moments amid crisis - Show everyday life continuing during drama - Allow for mood shifts that feel natural The key might be to trust that the core situation (something moving in a crate) is inherently compelling enough that we don't need to "perfect" it with neat plot structures and clear moral lessons. A human writer might let the situation unfold more organically, following character reactions rather than plot requirements, and allowing for the messiness that makes stories feel real.
Ok now with these considerations in mind, formulate the final plan for the a humanlike, compelling short piece in {n_chapters} chapters. Bear in mind the constraints of the piece (each chapter is just 1000 words). Above all things, the plan must serve the original prompt. We will use the same format as before: # Intention <State your formulated intentions for the piece, synthesised from the the parts of the brainstorming session that worked, and avoiding the parts that didn't. Be explicit about the choices you have made about plot, voice, stylistic choices, things you intend to aim for & avoid.> # Chapter Planning <Write a brief chapter plan for all {n_chapters} chapters.>
Model Output:
# Intention A taut, character-driven piece that honors the visceral unease of the original prompt: "something's moving in that crate." The story will follow Captain Chen of the cargo ship Dustrunner, whose carefully maintained routine of barely-profitable runs gets upended by a crate that shouldn't be moving. Core Approach: - Keep the focus tight on the immediate situation - Let character flaws and practicalities complicate decisions - Write in close third person, staying with Chen's perspective - Trust in small moments and telling details - Embrace the horror of the ordinary - Allow humor to emerge naturally from tension - Leave some questions unanswered Stylistic Choices: - Sparse, direct prose - Emphasis on sensory details - Dialogue that feels overheard rather than written - Show the grind of space travel through small details - Let Western elements emerge through situation rather than style Things to Avoid: - Neat moral lessons - Excessive worldbuilding - Perfect character arcs - Tidy resolutions - Explaining too much # Chapter Planning Chapter 1: "Routine" - Chen dealing with ship's chronic coolant leak - Regular pickup from Frontier Corp loading dock - Odd behavior from usually bored dock workers - That sound from the cargo hold that can't be what it seems - Focus on establishing the mundane before it breaks Chapter 2: "Professional" - Chen trying to ignore the situation - Engineer Patel insisting on checking it out - Ship's systems acting up (as usual) - Growing unease as sounds become undeniable - End with Chen making the call she doesn't want to make Chapter 3: "Protocol" - Corporate response too quick, too interested - Crew splitting time between regular duties and watching crate - Chen's attempt to maintain normalcy failing - Discovery of surveillance device in cargo manifest - Patel's scan results don't make sense Chapter 4: "Breach" - Crate opens itself - What emerges isn't what anyone expected - Crew's reactions range from practical to paranoid - Chen's immediate problem: where to put it - Corporate rep's arrival imminent Chapter 5: "Complications" - Corporate rep turns out to be former crew - Ship's coolant system finally fails - Forced stop at mining outpost - Thing from crate shows signs of intelligence - Chen's authority starting to slip Chapter 6: "Choice" - Corporate backup arriving - Crew divisions deepen - Mining outpost politics interfere - Chen realizes the truth about the cargo - No good options left Chapter 7: "Run" - Plan goes wrong immediately - Ship problems get worse - Unexpected help from unlikely source - Corporate pursuit - Thing from crate makes its own decisions Chapter 8: "After" - Dealing with immediate aftermath - Some problems solved, others created - Crew relationships permanently altered - No clean resolution - Final scene: Chen getting a new cargo offer Notes: - The "thing" in the crate remains somewhat ambiguous - Ship problems are constant background tension - Corporate threat comes from system rather than evil - Focus stays on immediate problems rather than larger implications - End leaves questions about what comes next Each chapter needs to maintain forward momentum while allowing for the small moments that make it feel real. The 1000-word constraint means focusing on essential scenes and letting implications do heavy lifting.
Perfect. Now with the outline more crystallised, and bearing in mind the discussion on human writing vs LLM pitfalls, we will flesh out our characters. Lets go through each of our main characters: - Write about their background, personality, idiosyncracies, flaws. Be specific and come up with examples to anchor & ground the character's profile (both core and trivial) - Briefly describe their physicality: appearance, how they carry themselves, express, interact with the world. - Concisely detail their motives, allegiences and existing relationships. Think from the perspective of the character as a real breathing thinking feeling individual in this world. - Write a couple quotes of flavour dialogue / internal monologue from the character to experiment with their voice. Output like this: # Character 1 name <character exploration> # Character 2 name <character exploration> etc
Model Output:
# Captain Sarah Chen Background & Personality: - Third-generation cargo runner who inherited a failing business and dying ship from her mother - Practical to a fault - would rather fix something with tape than pay for proper repairs - Deals with stress by obsessively organizing the ship's inventory - Has a collection of ancient Earth coins she won't sell despite constant money problems - Terrible at maintaining relationships but oddly good with difficult clients - Can't sleep without the ship's engines running - Known for eating the same meal for weeks until she gets sick of it Physicality: - Mid-40s, compact build from years in low gravity - Moves with deliberate efficiency, hates wasting motion - Habitually cracks her knuckles when thinking - Always wears her mother's old cargo jacket despite it being too big - Has a slight limp from a badly-healed fracture she couldn't afford to treat properly Motives & Relationships: - Desperately wants to keep the ship running, not just for money but because it's home - Treats crew like family but keeps emotional distance - Deep-seated distrust of corporations from watching them squeeze out independent operators - Loyalty to other small-time runners, will help even at a loss Voice: Internal: "Mother always said a quiet ship's a dead ship. This one's too damn quiet." Dialogue: "Look, we can fix the coolant leak or we can make this delivery on time. Pick one. And before you ask - no, we can't afford both." # Raj Patel (Engineer) Background & Personality: - Corporate engineering dropout who chose freedom over security - Perpetually working on a "revolutionary" engine modification - Talks to the ship's systems like they're pets - Hides snacks all over the engine room "for emergencies" - Brilliant with machines, awkward with people - Keeps detailed logs of every repair, including conversations with equipment - Can't stand silence, always humming or talking to himself Physicality: - Early 30s, tall and gangly - Constantly in motion, fidgeting with tools or components - Has burns on his hands from rushing repairs - Wears magnetic boots even when gravity's working - Hair always sticks up from running his hands through it Motives & Relationships: - Sees the ship as a puzzle to be solved - Secretly afraid of being forced back to corporate work - Protective of Chen, though she drives him crazy - Has a crush on the corporate rep that everyone knows about except him Voice: Internal: "If I bypass the secondary coolant loop... no, no, that would kill us all. But maybe..." Dialogue: "Captain, I know it sounds bad, but that noise is actually better than the noise it was making yesterday!" # Maya Santos (Security Officer) Background & Personality: - Ex-colonial militia who left after seeing too much corruption - Keeps weapon maintenance tools in her personal mess kit - Has a secret soft spot for old romance novels - Terrible cook but insists on making meals for the crew - Surprisingly good at origami - Can't sleep more than four hours at a time - Claims to have once won a drinking contest with a mining bot Physicality: - Late 30s, muscular but moving slower these days - Favors her right side from an old injury - Always positions herself with view of exits - Unconsciously checks corners when entering rooms - Has a collection of scars she won't talk about Motives & Relationships: - Wants to protect the crew but struggles with trust - Considers Chen the only authority she respects anymore - Keeps tabs on everyone's movements out of habit - Haunted by past failures to protect others Voice: Internal: "Three entry points, two potential weapons, four steps to the nearest cover..." Dialogue: "Sure, everything's fine. I just like standing here with my gun because it's comfortable." [Would you like me to continue with more characters, such as the Corporate Rep and any other crew members?]

Chapter 1

Great. Now let's write this. Follow your plan. Output chapter 1, without any additional commentary. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Routine Captain Chen wedged herself deeper into the maintenance shaft, stretching until her fingers brushed the leaking coolant line. The tape was right there in her pocket, but reaching it meant letting go of the handhold. She muttered a curse in Mandarin and glanced down the shaft's length. Twenty meters to the bottom. Bad way to die, that. "Captain?" Patel's voice crackled through her earpiece. "Dock's calling. They're ready for pickup." "Tell them to wait." The tape was starting to curl off the line again, revealing hairline cracks in the metal beneath. She should replace the whole section. Should've replaced it three months ago. "They're saying the manifest requires immediate loading." Chen pressed the fresh strip of tape down, smoothing out the bubbles. "Since when do Frontier Corp dockworkers care about immediate anything?" "They seem... agitated." That made her pause. In fifteen years of running cargo through Beta Station, she'd never seen a Frontier Corp worker agitated about anything except their break times. The coolant line hummed under her fingers. The tape would hold. Probably. "Fine," she said. "Tell them we're coming. And Patel? Get the backup cooling loop running. Just in case." The Dustrunner's cargo bay was empty except for Wei's old mag-loader squatting in the corner. Chen patted its worn housing as she passed. The loader was older than her, but it still worked. Most days. She found Patel waiting by the airlock, tablet in hand, foot tapping that nervous rhythm he couldn't control. "Manifest is weird," he said without looking up. "Weird how?" "Single item. Heavy. They're charging us premium rates for atmospheric control." Chen leaned over his shoulder. The manifest was bare except for a string of numbers and letters that meant nothing to her. "Payment cleared already?" "That's the other thing." Patel showed her the transfer receipt. Chen whistled. "Double rate?" "Triple." He finally looked up, dark eyes worried. "Captain, last time we got triple rate-" "Was that run to Europa, I know." The run that had ended with Santos shooting out their own engine to keep something from getting to the colonies. They didn't talk about Europa anymore. "This isn't that. It's just a box." The docking tube cycled green. Chen squared her shoulders, touched the coin hanging at her neck for luck, and stepped through. Four dockworkers waited with the crate. Chen had never seen one like it - matte black, three meters long, with status lights blinking along its side. No markings except the Frontier Corp logo. "Sign here," said the nearest worker, throat mic distorting his voice. His hands were shaking. Chen took the tablet, scanning the contract. "Contents?" "Classified. Sign." She signed. The money was too good to push it. The workers moved fast, securing the crate to their loader. Too fast. Like they couldn't wait to be rid of it. Chen watched them practically run back through the tube. "Well," she said to Patel, "that was-" A thump echoed through the cargo bay. Chen froze. "Did you hear-" Another thump. Definitely from the crate. "Patel," she said carefully, "what are the atmospheric settings showing?" He checked his tablet. "Standard pressure, standard mix. Temperature control drawing more power than it should for an inert cargo space." The crate was silent now. Chen approached it slowly, pressing her hand against its surface. Warm. She could feel vibrations through her palm, like something spinning up or winding down. "Captain?" Patel's voice was higher than usual. "Should we-" "Log shows this is a twelve-hour run to Gamma Station," she said. "Simple delivery. We're getting paid enough to fix the coolant line properly, maybe even get Wei's loader serviced." "But-" "Plot the course, Patel. I'll be on the bridge." She left him staring at the crate, his tablet forgotten in his hands. In the corridor, she tried to raise Santos on the comm. "Yeah, Captain?" "We've got a situation. Maybe nothing. Probably nothing. But-" A sound cut through the ship's ambient noise. Not a thump this time. More like... scratching. Chen closed her eyes. Opened them. "Maya? Bring your gear to the cargo bay. Don't tell the others yet." "That bad?" "Let's hope not." She touched the coin again, her mother's voice echoing in her head. A quiet ship's a dead ship. The Dustrunner hummed around her, engines spinning up, coolant lines creaking, and underneath it all, so faint she might be imagining it, something moving in the cargo bay. Triple rate, she thought. It's just a box. She didn't believe it either.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 1)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This opening chapter establishes a solid foundation for a space western, efficiently introducing Captain Chen and her world while building tension around the mysterious crate. The chapter follows its outlined plan quite faithfully, hitting all the intended beats: the coolant leak maintenance, the routine pickup turned unusual, the dock workers' strange behavior, and the unsettling sounds from the cargo. The characterization of Captain Chen is nuanced and consistent with her profile. The details about her practical nature (using tape for repairs), her physical traits (like wedging herself into tight spaces), and her relationship with her ship all effectively establish her character. The narrative uses small actions and decisions to reveal her personality rather than exposition. The prose is restrained and purposeful, avoiding the common pitfall of overwriting in science fiction. Details like "She touched the coin again, her mother's voice echoing in her head" provide just enough character background without bogging down the narrative. The writing maintains a careful balance between technical specificity and accessibility. Dialogue is economical and character-revealing. Each character's speech patterns reflect their role and personality, particularly Patel's anxious questioning and the dock workers' terse interactions. However, the dialogue could occasionally benefit from more distinctive voices - there are moments when the characters' speech patterns feel somewhat similar. The plot progresses with well-managed tension, using the crew's financial need to justify taking on suspicious cargo - a classic western trope effectively translated to space. The mention of the previous "Europa" incident cleverly hints at backstory without derailing the present narrative. The chapter effectively "shows" rather than "tells" in most instances, using sensory details like the humming coolant line, the vibrations felt through Chen's palm, and the scratching sounds to build atmosphere. However, there are a few instances where more sensory detail could enhance immersion, particularly regarding the station environment. While the chapter skillfully establishes the space western setting, some elements feel familiar to the genre - the struggling independent operator, the mysterious cargo, the corporation in the background. The basic setup, while well-executed, follows recognizable patterns. That said, the attention to practical details like maintenance issues and financial pressures gives authenticity to this otherwise familiar framework. The chapter maintains coherence throughout, with clear cause-and-effect relationships and logical character motivations. The pacing is effective, moving from routine maintenance to growing unease in a measured progression. The chapter establishes a tone of practical problem-solving meets creeping dread, which works well for the space western genre. The emotional engagement comes from Chen's conflicted decision-making and the crew's mounting tension rather than from explicit emotional states. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 15 Compelling Plot: 16 Coherent: 18 Weak Dialogue: 5 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 7 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 2 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 16 Characters Consistent with Profile: 18 Followed Chapter Plan: 19 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 18

Chapter 2

Ok now chapter 2. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Professional Chen stared at the cargo manifest for the fourth time, pretending she couldn't hear it. The scratching had stopped, but something else had started - a rhythmic tapping, like someone drumming fingers against metal. If she focused on the manifest, maybe it would go away. Santos stood at the cargo bay entrance, one hand resting on her holstered gun. She hadn't moved in an hour. "Could be mechanical," Chen said, not looking up. "Some kind of automated system cycling." "Sure, Captain." Santos shifted her weight. "That's why I'm standing here with my gun." The tapping changed rhythm. Almost like it was responding. Chen's tablet chimed - Patel requesting a video call. She accepted. "Captain?" His face filled the screen, lit by the engine room's red emergency lights. "The atmospheric controls are... well, you should see this." He flipped his camera. Power consumption graphs pulsed across his monitor, spiking and falling in regular patterns. "It's breathing," he said. "Whatever's in there, it's breathing." Chen ended the call. The manifest still showed nothing useful - just strings of numbers and corporate codes. She could call Frontier Corp, demand answers. But answers meant complications, and complications meant- The tapping stopped. Santos drew her gun in one smooth motion. "Captain?" "Wait." Chen held up her hand. "Just wait." Silence stretched out. Chen counted her heartbeats. One. Two. Three- A bang echoed through the cargo bay, loud enough to make them both jump. The crate shuddered against its restraints. "That's it." Santos moved forward. "We need to-" "Stand down." Chen's voice was sharper than she intended. "We're being paid to transport, not investigate." "With respect, Captain, that's stupid and you know it." Another bang. The crate's status lights flickered. Chen's earpiece crackled. "Bridge to Captain." Rodriguez, their pilot, sounded tense. "We've got an incoming transmission from Frontier Corp. Marked urgent." Of course they were calling. Chen pressed her fingers against her temples. "Put them through to my tablet." The corporate logo filled her screen, replaced by a woman with close-cropped gray hair and the kind of smile that cost money. "Captain Chen. I'm Director Walsh. We've been notified of some anomalous readings from our cargo." "Have you?" Chen kept her voice neutral. "Nothing to be concerned about. Standard automated systems." Walsh's smile didn't waver. "However, we'd appreciate if you could adjust your course. A representative will meet you at Beta Station instead of Gamma. We'll compensate you for the extra time, of course." The crate shuddered again. Santos took another step forward. "That's a six-hour deviation," Chen said. "Fuel costs-" "Will be covered. Plus a bonus. The transfer is already processing." Chen's tablet chimed. The number made her breath catch. "Do we have an understanding, Captain?" The tapping started again, faster now. Desperate. "Understood," Chen said. "Course adjustment in progress." Walsh's smile widened. "Excellent. One more thing - please ensure no one approaches the cargo. For safety reasons." The transmission cut off. Chen looked at Santos, who hadn't lowered her gun. "Safety reasons," Santos repeated. "Right." "Maya-" "Don't. Don't tell me this is fine. Don't tell me to be professional." Santos gestured at the crate with her gun. "You know what this reminds me of? Europa." "This isn't Europa." "No? Rich corps, secret cargo, changing routes?" Santos stepped closer, lowering her voice. "Captain, after Europa, you promised. No more black box jobs." The tapping was getting louder. Chen could feel it through the deck plates now. "Bridge to Captain," Rodriguez called again. "Course adjusted. But... we might have a problem." "What kind of problem?" "Two corporate ships just appeared on long-range sensors. Moving fast." Chen closed her eyes. Opened them. The crate's status lights were pulsing in sequence now, like a countdown. "Captain?" Santos was waiting for an order. Chen touched her mother's coin. Thought about the coolant line, held together with tape and prayers. Thought about Walsh's smile and Europa and promises she'd made. "Maya," she said quietly, "lock the cargo bay doors. Patel?" "Here, Captain." "Get down here with your scanner. We're being professional about this." "What does that mean?" Chen watched the status lights pulse. Red. Yellow. Green. "It means we're going to do our jobs. Thoroughly. Carefully." She managed a tight smile. "We're going to inspect this cargo for any potential hazards. As any professional crew would." Santos finally lowered her gun, grinning. "Knew you'd make the right call." "The right call is debatable." Chen pulled up the ship's schematics, calculating distances to the nearest airlock. Just in case. "Let's see what we're really being paid to carry." The tapping stopped again. This time, it was replaced by something worse. Something that sounded almost like words.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 2)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter successfully builds tension around the mysterious crate while developing character dynamics and establishing a corporate conspiracy subplot. The author maintains a tight focus on Captain Chen's perspective as she struggles between professional obligation and growing suspicion. The writing effectively conveys the lived-in quality of the ship and crew relationships. Small details like Chen's habit of organizing inventory when stressed and her mother's coin ground her character. The sparse, direct prose style suits the space western genre without falling into clichés. Character consistency is strong, with Chen's practical nature conflicting with her moral compass, Santos maintaining security vigilance, and Patel's technical focus all aligning with their profiles. The callbacks to past events ("Europa") create intriguing backstory without excessive exposition. Dialogue functions well as a tension-building tool, particularly in the exchange with Director Walsh, where corporate pleasantries barely mask menace. The contrast between Walsh's polished demeanor and the crew's wariness creates an effective power dynamic. The pacing is particularly well-handled. The author builds suspense through escalating phenomena: scratching becomes tapping, then banging, then something "almost like words." This progression, combined with the revelation of approaching corporate ships, creates a compelling cliffhanger. Some minor weaknesses include occasional telling rather than showing, particularly in describing Santos's emotional state rather than demonstrating it through action. The "rich corps, secret cargo" dialogue spells out the situation too explicitly when it could have been implied. The mystery of what's in the crate remains appropriately ambiguous while giving enough hints (breathing patterns, communication attempts) to maintain reader interest. The chapter succeeds in making both the crate and the corporation feel threatening in different ways. Overall, the chapter fulfills its planned function in the narrative arc while establishing stakes and character motivations that will drive the story forward. It balances immediate tension with hints of larger worldbuilding without overwhelming the immediate scene. Chapter 3

Ok now chapter 3. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Protocol The scanner in Patel's hands chirped steadily, each sound making Chen's headache worse. They'd been at this for an hour, and all they had were questions. "That's not possible," Patel muttered, smacking the scanner. "These readings make no sense." "Try making sense of them anyway." Chen watched the corporate ships on her tablet. Still matching their course, still maintaining distance. Playing escort without admitting it. The crate had gone quiet after that almost-voice, but its status lights kept cycling. Red. Yellow. Green. Like a threat, or a promise. "Mass readings are all wrong," Patel said. "Temperature's fluctuating. And there's some kind of..." He trailed off, frowning at the screen. "Some kind of what?" "Signal. Buried in the atmospheric control feed. Could be a monitoring system." Santos, who'd been checking the manifest casing, straightened up. "They're watching us." "Not exactly." Patel touched commands on his tablet. "More like... checking vitals?" That word hung in the air. Vitals. Chen remembered Walsh's smile, her careful choice of words. Safety reasons. "Captain?" Rodriguez's voice in her ear. "Corporate ships are requesting status update." "Tell them everything's nominal." Chen moved closer to the crate, pitching her voice low. "Patel, can you isolate that signal? Block it?" "Maybe. But they'd know." "Do it anyway. Carefully." Santos appeared at her shoulder. "Found something. Hidden compartment in the manifest case." She held up a small black disc. "Surveillance device. Audio only, looks like." "Wonderful." Chen took the disc, studying it. Standard corporate tech, the kind you could buy anywhere. Which meant the real surveillance was probably better hidden. "Leave it active. Give them something to listen to." "What's the play, Captain?" Chen didn't answer immediately. The crate's surface was warm under her fingers, vibrating slightly. She thought about the money in their account, enough to fix everything that needed fixing. Thought about Europa. "We play it by the book," she said finally. "For now. Maya, start a security log. Note down every reading, every noise. Raj, keep working on that signal. If they're monitoring vitals, I want to know exactly what kind of vitals we're talking about." "And the corporate ships?" Santos asked. "We-" The crate shuddered. Not the violent movement from before, but something subtler. Like a tremor, or a shiver. Patel's scanner screamed. "Power spike! It's-" The cargo bay lights cut out. Chen's tablet flashed emergency warnings. Main power drop, backup systems engaging. In the darkness, the crate's status lights burned brighter. Red. Yellow. Green. "Raj..." "Working on it!" She heard him scrambling with equipment. "Something's drawing massive power. Like it's charging up or-" The lights came back. Chen blinked away afterimages. "Rodriguez? Status?" "Systems restoring. But Captain... the corporate ships are closing in." Of course they were. Chen looked at Santos, saw her own decision reflected in the security officer's eyes. They were out of time for playing it safe. "Maya, get the cutting gear. Raj, forget the signal. Lock down every system you can - I don't want any more surprises. Rodriguez, maintain course but be ready for my mark." "Captain?" Rodriguez sounded worried. "What are we doing?" "Breaking protocol." Chen pulled up the cargo contract on her tablet, scanning terms and conditions. "Technically, we're required to inspect any cargo that shows signs of system interference. Article 47-B." Santos grinned. "Love it when you get technical." "Don't celebrate yet." Chen sent Rodriguez updated coordinates. "Corporate's not going to like this. If we're opening this thing, we're doing it somewhere we can handle the consequences." "Where?" "Mining outpost KG-17. Independent operation, owes me a favor. Two hours away if we push it." "The corps will catch us before then," Santos said. "Maybe." Chen watched the status lights pulse. Red. Yellow. Green. "But they'll have to be obvious about it. No more pretending this is routine." Her tablet chimed. Another transmission from Walsh. "Captain Chen." The corporate director's smile was gone. "Our sensors indicate unauthorized interference with the cargo systems. This is a violation of contract terms. Return to your assigned course immediately." "Director." Chen kept her voice professional. "According to Article 47-B, we are required to inspect cargo showing signs of system interference. We're following standard protocol." "This is not a standard situation." "No," Chen agreed. "It's not. But unless you want to tell me exactly what we're carrying, we'll handle it according to regulations." Walsh's face hardened. "You're making a mistake." "Wouldn't be my first." Chen ended the transmission. The crate shivered again. The almost-voice was back, clearer now. Still not quite words, but getting closer. "Captain?" Patel's scanner was showing new readings. "Whatever's in there... I think it knows what we're doing." Chen touched her mother's coin. Thought about mistakes and consequences and the look on Walsh's face. "Good," she said. "Maybe it can tell us if we're doing the right thing." Red. Yellow. Green. The race was on.
+ Judge Evaluation (Chapter 3)
Judge Response:
[Analysis] This chapter effectively builds tension while advancing the plot established in the writing plan. The author successfully creates a claustrophobic atmosphere centered around the mysterious crate and growing corporate pressure. Character dynamics are handled with notable skill. Captain Chen's pragmatic leadership comes through in her decision-making process, though her internal conflict could have been developed more deeply. The character interactions feel authentic to their established profiles - Patel's technical focus, Santos' security-minded perspective, and Chen's practical leadership approach all align with their character descriptions. The plot advances at an appropriate pace for a third chapter, with the discovery of surveillance, unexplained readings, and the decision to break protocol all creating compelling forward momentum. The corporate ships pursuing them adds urgency that propels the narrative. Dialogue is functional but occasionally utilitarian, with some exchanges serving primarily to move the plot rather than reveal character. Lines like "Try making sense of them anyway" and "What's the play, Captain?" feel serviceable but not particularly distinctive. The prose avoids purple excesses while still creating atmosphere through sensory details. The recurring image of the status lights (Red. Yellow. Green.) is effectively deployed without becoming overwrought. However, some descriptions could benefit from more specificity - phrases like "That word hung in the air" and "like a threat, or a promise" verge on generic. The chapter succeeds in its "show-don't-tell" moments, particularly in how the crate's movements and power drain are depicted. However, there are instances where emotional reactions are named rather than demonstrated, such as "saw her own decision reflected in the security officer's eyes." The plot development, while consistent with the chapter plan, doesn't offer many surprising turns. The corporate intervention and decision to divert course follow somewhat predictable space western tropes, though they're executed competently. Overall, the chapter demonstrates solid craft while adhering to genre expectations. It successfully advances the story while maintaining the established tone and character relationships. [Scores] Nuanced Characters: 14 Emotionally Engaging: 13 Compelling Plot: 15 Coherent: 17 Weak Dialogue: 7 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 4 Purple Prose: 3 Forced Poetry or Metaphor: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 15 Characters Consistent with Profile: 16 Followed Chapter Plan: 18 Faithful to Writing Prompt: 17

Chapter 4

Ok now chapter 4. Follow your plan. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Breach They were thirty minutes from the mining outpost when the crate decided to open itself. Chen was arguing with Rodriguez about approach vectors when the cargo bay alarms triggered. The status lights had gone dark. The atmospheric controls were cycling wildly. And the crate's seals were disengaging, one by one. "Get back!" Santos shoved Chen behind a cargo container. "Raj, shut it down!" "I can't!" Patel's fingers flew over his tablet. "It's not responding to anything!" A hiss of equalizing pressure. Then a sound Chen had never heard before - like metal stretching, or singing, or screaming. The crate's surface rippled. "Captain?" Rodriguez's voice was tight. "Corporate ships are charging weapons." Chen barely heard him. The crate was... changing. Its walls weren't splitting or opening - they were flowing, like black mercury, pulling away from something inside. Santos raised her gun. Patel clutched his scanner. Chen held her breath. The something inside moved. Later, Chen would struggle to describe what she saw. It was like watching light bend through water, or heat waves over metal. A shape that wasn't quite a shape, shifting between forms like it couldn't decide what to be. Then it stabilized, and Chen found herself staring at... a box. A simple metal box, half the size of the crate that had held it. No status lights. No corporate logos. Just smooth, dull surfaces and what looked like an old-fashioned manual latch. "That's it?" Santos kept her gun trained on it. "That's what all this was about?" Patel checked his scanner. "Power readings are minimal now. But there's definitely something alive in there." "Alive how?" The box clicked. The latch turned. "Everyone back," Chen ordered. "Maya, if anything hostile comes out-" "Already on it, Captain." The box opened. Chen had imagined a lot of possibilities. Weapons. Experiments. Some corporate horror they weren't meant to see. What she hadn't imagined was a child. The girl looked about twelve, with dark skin and close-cropped hair. She wore simple gray clothes with no markings. Her eyes, when she opened them, were silver. "Hello," she said. Her voice had an odd resonance, like multiple people speaking just slightly out of sync. "Are you the ones who heard me?" Nobody moved. Nobody spoke. The girl sat up, movements careful and precise. "The others never hear me," she continued in that strange voice. "They just transport. But you heard. You listened." Santos found her voice first. "Captain..." "I see her." Chen stepped forward slowly. "I'm Captain Chen. This is my ship. Can you tell us who you are?" The girl tilted her head. "I am Experiment 17-C. But the researcher who made me called me Clara." She looked around the cargo bay. "Are we still going to the processing facility?" "Processing facility?" Chen kept her voice calm. "Is that what's at Gamma Station?" "Yes. That's where they separate us. The successful from the failed." Clara's silver eyes fixed on Chen. "I don't want to be separated." A new alarm blared. "Captain!" Rodriguez sounded panicked now. "Corporate ships are in firing range!" Chen looked at the girl. At Santos's raised gun. At Patel's scanner showing life signs that made no sense. At the black liquid metal of the original crate, still flowing like something alive. "Clara," she said carefully, "are there others like you?" "Many. But not like me exactly. I'm the only one who can..." She gestured at the liquid metal. "They want to know how I do it. That's why they're sending me for processing." "Captain," Santos warned, "corporate ships are charging main guns." Chen made her decision. "Clara, we're not taking you to the processing facility. But I need to know - are you dangerous?" Those silver eyes blinked. "Everyone is dangerous, Captain Chen. Even you." "Fair enough." Chen turned to her crew. "Maya, get her to medical. Raj, see what you can do with that liquid metal - might be useful. Rodriguez, plot course for the mining outpost, full burn." "And the corporate ships?" Chen smiled grimly. "Tell them if they fire on us, they risk damaging their 'cargo.' Then ask if they're ready to explain to their bosses why they destroyed something this valuable." The first shots came close enough to rock the ship, but didn't hit. Warning fire. Chen watched Clara navigate the cargo bay with those too-precise movements. "Captain?" The girl paused at the doorway. "The others. In the other transports. They're afraid." "Other transports?" "Many ships. Many like me. All afraid." Chen touched her coin. Thought about her mother's voice. About Europa. About mistakes and consequences. "Rodriguez," she called, "get me a channel to every independent operator in range. And Clara?" She met those silver eyes. "Let's talk about these others." The girl smiled. It was almost human. Almost. "Captain?" Santos still hadn't lowered her gun. "What are we doing?" Chen watched the corporate ships on her tablet, thinking about what came next. About the weight of decisions. About the difference between right and smart. "We're about to make a very big mistake," she said. "Or maybe fix an old one. Probably both."
